nodes.text: State-level economic policy uncertainty can be measured and decomposed into state/local sources and national/international sources, and these measures matter for state economic performance
We construct three monthly state-level EPU indexes per state: EPU-S (state/local), EPU-N (national/international), and EPU-C (composite)
Newspaper-based measures are appropriate for frequent, subnational uncertainty indexes because digital archives provide many local papers over long time spans and topical textual detail

We flag articles that contain an economy term, an uncertainty term, and a policy term (state-specific for EPU-S, national for EPU-N), compute raw article fractions, and normalize by a 2006-2019 baseline to produce indexed monthly values
The dataset taps nearly 3,500 local newspapers, median 49 papers per state-month, covering 1985 to 2021 (varies by state); indexes and replication files are publicly available
Half of articles in the composite index discuss state/local policy, so subnational matters are major sources of state-level EPU

EPU-S and EPU-N show distinct temporal and cross-state patterns: EPU-S spikes around gubernatorial elections and state episodes; EPU-N spikes around presidential elections and major national/international events

The relative importance of state vs national sources varies across states (ratio EPU-S/EPU-N from 0.35 to 1.51) and increased after COVID (cross-state average 0.65 pre-pandemic to 1.1 March 2020–June 2021)
COVID-19 caused huge increases in both EPU-N and especially EPU-S, with stricter state lockdowns associated with larger increases in state EPU-C
Close elections (winning margin <4%) raise policy uncertainty substantially: a close presidential contest raises EPU-N by about 60% and a close gubernatorial contest raises EPU-S by about 35%

Selected national events (9-11, debt-ceiling crisis, Brexit, Trump election, government shutdowns) produced large cross-state EPU-N spikes; selected state episodes (California electricity crisis, Kansas tax experiment, Hurricane Katrina) produced large EPU-S spikes

Panel VARs (44 states, 2001–2019) show upward own-state EPU-C shocks foreshadow higher unemployment and lower employment with hump-shaped peaks about one year later; effects are modest but precisely estimated
Spatial VAR extensions show that upward EPU shocks in bordering states also raise own-state unemployment; own-state and border-state shocks of equal size have similar unemployment impacts

California case study: realized EPU-C shocks during the 2000-01 electricity crisis materially raised California unemployment (historical decomposition shows up to ~2 percentage points attributable to EPU shocks)

During COVID, cross-state variation in lockdown stringency (measured from shelter-in-place, business, restaurant, and school closure orders) predicts cross-state variation in EPU increases and in unemployment increases; COVID deaths per capita do not predict EPU increases

Conclusion: state-level EPU indexes are useful for studying subnational policy uncertainty sources, election effects, pandemic impacts, cross-border spillovers, and links from uncertainty to state economic outcomes; indexes are publicly available for further research
